column10: and prepare charts illustrating data by region    •  Compiles and analyzes data from studies and surveys and integrates information into   comprehensive planning reports    •  Analyzes and evaluates research data in the areas of population

column1: 19022`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2016construction/mar_2016/20160307_Trumbull_27w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1601027   March 7
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure  investment program
column5: I would like to provide you with  information about an upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By mid March 2016
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark  Construction Company crews will begin the work to install 1
column7: 718 feet of new 8-inch water  main in N. Trumbull Avenue
column8: from W. Grand Avenue to 160 feet north of W. Chicago  Avenue. The old water main dates back to 1901
column9: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column10: please  go to BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter  your name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column12: you will be notified as the project enters each  new construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column13: to the  installation of new pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column15: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but  you will always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel  lane will be left open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the  start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column19: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column20: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column21: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311   •  27th Ward Office: 312-432-1995  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column22: we will  interrupt water service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column23: in  the event of an emergency shutdown during construction
column24: we may not be able to give you  prior warning.   After the old water main has been replaced and you have been connected to the new water  main
column25: please open all your water faucets and hose taps and flush your water for at least 5  minutes.  The aerator screens located at the tip of your faucets should be removed prior to  flushing.    This flushing will help maintain optimum water quality by removing sediment
column27: or any  lead particulates that may have come loose from your property’s water service line as a  result of the water main replacement.  If you have any questions or concerns about your  water quality
column28: please call us at 312-744-8190.   It is advised that you flush your water line for 5 minutes
column29: if it has been idle or stagnant for  more than 6-hours.   Lastly
column30: if you don’t already have one
column31: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column32: go to www.metersave.org   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.     Sincerely

column1: 10442`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/ethics/general/AO_ConflictOfInterest/00008-AO-redact.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`ADVISORY OPINION CASE NO.  00008.A  To: Re:  Staff Participation in [the] making [of] a governmental decision  Date: April 20
column2: 2000  The  Board  of  Ethics  has  considered  staff’s  request  of  April  6
column3: 2000  for  an advisory  opinion  interpreting  the  phrase  “participate  in  [the]  making  [of]  a governmental decision
column4: ” as used in sections 2-156-030(a) and 2-156-080(a) of the Governmental Ethics Ordinance.   This advisory opinion is based on the hypothetical facts presented by staff
column5: and its application is limited to those facts.      FACTS:    Staff presents two sets of hypothetical facts:   Hypothetical  One.    A  City  employee  or  official  sits  as  a  member  of  a  City agency
column6: board or commission.   During the course of a hearing conducted before that  body
column7: the  City official or employee examines a witness.  A vote
column8: from which the employee or official recuses himself
column10: board or commission at the conclusion of the hearing
column11: resulting in a decision or action by that body.    Hypothetical  Two.    A    City  employee  or  official  sits  as  the  chair  of  a  City agency
column12: board or commission.  The City official or employee presides over a hearing conducted before that body.  The City official examines no witnesses during  the  hearing.  A  vote
column13: from  which  the  employee  or  official  recuses himself
column15: board or commission at the conclusion of the hearing
column16: resulting in a decision or action by that body.    RELEVANT  ORDINANCE  PROVISIONS:  (Improper Influence) states:    Section  2-156-030(a)  No  official  or  employee  shall  make
column17: participate  in  making  or  in  any  way attempt  to  use  his  position  to  influence  any  City  governmental  decision  or action in which he knows or has reason to know that he has any economic interest  distinguishable  from  its  effect  on  the  public  generally  (emphasis added).  Section 2-156-080(a) (Conflicts of Interest) states:  No  official  or  employee  shall  make  or  participate  in  the  making  of  any governmental decision with respect to any matter in which he has any economic interest distinguishable from that of the general public  (emphasis added).  Case No.  00008.A April 20
column18: 2000 Page 2    QUESTIONS PRESENTED:   1.   2.  Does a City employee or official participate in [the] making [of] a governmental decision
column19: within the meaning of sections 2-156-030(a) and 2-156-080(a) of the Governmental Ethics Ordinance
column21: as a member of a City agency
column23: he examines a witness testifying during a hearing before that body which results in a decision or action by that body?   Does a City employee or official participate in [the] making [of] a governmental decision
column24: within the meaning of sections 2-156-030(a) and 2-156-080(a) of the Governmental Ethics Ordinance
column25: if he presides over a  hearing  before a City  agency
column26: board or commission which results in a decision or action by that body?  BOARD PRECEDENT:  This is a case of first impression for the Board.  APPLICATION OF THE LAW TO THE FACTS: The phrase “participate in [the] making [of] a governmental decision” is not defined in the Governmental Ethics Ordinance.  Nor has the phrase been construed to date by Board opinion.  The  ordinary meaning of the word “participate” is “to join or share with others: take part.”  Webster’s II
column27: New Riverside University Dictionary  (1984).  With  regard  to  the  first  question
column28: the  Board  notes  that  Black’s  Law  Dictionary  defines  the “examination” of a witness as “...the series of questions put to him by a party to the action
column30: for the purpose of bringing before the  court...the knowledge which the witness has of the facts and matters in dispute
column31: or of probing and sifting his evidence previously given.”  Black’s Law Dictionary
column33: West (1979).  By virtue of the critical function an examination fulfills–the presentation and probing of evidence–the Board finds that “to examine a witness” during the course of a hearing
column34: in one’s capacity as a member of the body before which that hearing is being conducted
column35: is to “take part” in the hearing and
column37: in the ultimate decision made by that body
column38: even if one does not “take part” in the vote.      As to the second question
column39: the Board notes that Black’s Law Dictionary defines “preside” as “to occupy  the  place  of  authority  as  of  president
column43: control  or regulate proceedings as chief officer
column45: etc.; to possess or exercise authority....” Id.  By virtue  of  the  authority
column46: and  the  ability  to  direct  or  control
column47: inherent  in  the  position  of  one  who presides
column48: the Board finds that “to preside” over a hearing is to “take part” in the hearing and
column50: in the ultimate decision made by that body
column51: even if one does not “take part” in the examination of witnesses or in the vote.        DETERMINATIONS:   Accordingly
column52: the Board determines that:  Case No.  00008.A April 20
column53: 2000 Page 3    1.  2.  a City employee or official participates in [the] making [of] a governmental decision
column54: within the  meaning  of  sections  2-156-030(a)  and  2-156-080(a)  of  the  Governmental  Ethics Ordinance
column56: as a member of a City agency
column58: he examines a witness testifying during a hearing before that body which results in a decision or action by that body; and   a City employee or official participates in [the] making [of] a governmental decision
column59: within the  meaning  of  sections  2-156-030(a)  and  2-156-080(a)  of  the  Governmental  Ethics Ordinance
column60: if he presides over a  hearing  before a City  agency
column61: board or commission which results in a decision or action by that body.  Our determinations are not necessarily dispositive of all issues relevant to this situation
column62: but are based solely on the application of the City’s Governmental Ethics Ordinance to the facts stated in this opinion.  Other laws or rules also may apply to this situation.  Be advised that City departments have  the  authority  to  adopt  and  enforce  rules  of  conduct  that  may  be  more  restrictive  than  the limitations imposed by the Ethics Ordinance.   RELIANCE:  This opinion may be relied upon by any person involved in any specific transaction or activity indistinguishable in all its material aspects from the transaction or activity with respect to which the opinion is rendered.  __________________ Darryl L. DePriest Chair  I:\Redactions\Redacted Opinions\00008-AO-redact.wpd

column1: 7602`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2011cnstRpt/Lawndale4wd26_031111.pdf`Success`Success`4`4`Not a fillable PDF.`            WATER MANAGEMENT CUSTOMER NOTICE   March 11
column4: I am providing you with information regarding  an upcoming water construction project in your neighborhood. I want to be certain  you are well informed about the project
column5: and that you know where to call if you  have any questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing 1
column6: 320 feet of 8-inch water main in N. Lawndale  Avenue
column7: from W. Cortland Street to W. Armitage Avenue
column9: from W. Cortland Street to W. Armitage Avenue. The old main dates  back to 1887 and needs to be replaced.     We are coordinating with Alderman Maldonado’s office
column10: and he has made clear we  are to put great importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this  neighborhood through the whole term of this project. Good communication is the  key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor  the project closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences  and noise. We will do everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise  and to conduct ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our  presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column11: please feel free to contact  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1029 at any time
column12: you may leave  a message.     Thank you for your understanding and good will.     Sincerely
column14: P.E.   Commissioner       cc: Alderman Roberto Maldonado        26th Ward                                                       Do you wonder what was happening in 1887?  That’s the year the old water main was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:                                               Anne Sullivan began teaching 6 year old
column15: blind and deaf Helen Keller.    Oregon became the first state to make Labor Day a holiday.    Britain celebrated the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria.    Susanna Medora Salter was elected the first U.S. woman mayor (Argonia
column16: Kansas).    The fire escape was patented.    Boris Karloff
column18: was born.                    PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project: The Department of Water Management is installing 1
column19: 320 feet of 8-inch water main in  N. Lawndale Avenue
column20: from W. Cortland Street to W. Armitage Avenue
column22: from W. Cortland Street to W. Armitage Avenue.           Reason: The old main consists of 6-inch pipe
column23: and we want to expand capacity. Further
column24: the old  pipe dates back to 1887
column25: and we can expect increasingly frequent breaks if we don’t replace it.    Timing: Work starts in April
column26: and we expect the job to be completed in late June (restoration  will follow in late July). This
column28: is an estimate. Sometimes there are unexpected  developments in the street
column29: or other circumstances (e.g. weather) that force us to adjust our  schedules.      Traffic: We will allow traffic to flow on N. Lawndale Avenue and N. Monticello Avenue  without interruption
column30: but we will have to restrict parking around our work zone.    Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column31: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column32: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the  start of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.    Service Interruptions:  We will have to interrupt water service for a brief period when we  transfer service pipes to the new main.  This will always be done with plenty of notice.  The  other possibility is that a break in the old main might force an immediate shutdown.  This is  common during construction.  We are replacing some pretty old pipes. We will make sure  neighbors know what is happening if that occurs.     CONTACT NUMBERS         24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE   ALDERMAN ROBERTO MALDONADO   773-773-395-0143   3-1-1         312-742-1029   ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE      FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS        What if there is a problem?  There are always surprises in any construction project.  If you  have any concerns or questions
column33: you can ask our foreman in the street.  You can also call  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte directly at 312-742-1029.  His cell is on the voicemail  message
column34: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column35: the job is slated to conclude in late June.  Restoration will follow in late July. We always hesitate to promise specific dates
column36: since we are  at the mercy of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column37: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column38: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column39: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column40: we will let you  know what is happening
column41: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column42: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column43: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.

column1: 26075`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/GENERAL-SHOP-FOREMAN_6575.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code: 6575  Operation and Construction Service  Industrial Trades Group  Mechanical Trades Series             CLASS TITLE: General Shop Foreman    CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under general supervision
column2: the class  supervises the day to day shop operations at an assigned Department of  Fleet Management garage facility; and performs related duties as  required.    ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Oversees and monitors the inspection
column5: mechanical and electrical repairs of city  vehicles and equipment including automotive passenger
column7: medium and heavy duty trucks; supervises foremen and supervisory staff  responsible for assigning and directing the work of garage attendants
column8: service writers and skilled trades personnel; tracks the status of  open work orders to ensure the timely completion of repairs and  maintenance work; reviews work orders to ensure the timely completion  of repairs and maintenance work; reviews work orders and inspects  completed work for quality control; inspects and approves automotive  and structural/body repair work performed by outside vendors;  implements work standards and operating procedures and evaluates staff  performance; prepares work schedules and approves staffing assignments  to ensure proper staffing of facility; authorizes requests for the  procurement of automotive and equipment parts and supplies; monitors  the training of staff by vehicle manufacturers on automotive repairs  and standards; prepares productivity and vehicle maintenance reports.     MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience.  Six years of experience in the repair and  maintenance of automotive and trucking equipment
column9: supplemented by two  years of supervisory experience
column10: or an equivalent combination of  training and experience.     A  valid State of Illinois driver=s license is required.    Knowledge
column11: Abilities and Skill.  Considerable knowledge of the  operations of an automotive
column12: trucking and heavy duty off road  equipment repair and maintenance facility.  Considerable knowledge of  the work methods
column13: tools and equipment used in the diagnostic testing
column15: trucking and heavy duty off road  equipment.  Good knowledge of safety practices and procedures.  Good  knowledge of supervisory methods and practices.                                       Code: 6575  Operation and Construction Service  Industrial Trades Group  Mechanical Trades Series           CLASS TITLE: General Shop Foreman   (Cont=d)    Ability to manage a comprehensive repair and maintenance garage  facility.  Ability to manage repair work performed by vendors.   Ability to administer automotive and truck rental or leasing  contracts.       Good supervisory and management skills.  Good oral and written  communication skills.  Good skill in establishing and enforcing work  and safety procedures.  Good skill in preparing cost and productivity  reports.  Good human relations skills.    Working Conditions.  General office environment; unavoidable exposure  to extreme temperatures and exposure to fumes
column16: dust and noise.    Equipment.  Safety equipment.  Standard office equipment including  personal computers.             NOTE:    While the list of essential duties is intended to be as  inclusive as possible
column17: there may be other duties which are  essential to particular positions within the class.                          January

column1: 14612`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/cdph/emergency_preparedness/DieseaseOutbreaksandToxins_French.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`   Agents du bioterrorisme (lien vers la sous-page)    Bioterrorisme    Les Centres de contrôle et de prévention des maladies (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column2: CDC) définissent le bioterrorisme comme étant l’utilisation intentionnelle de virus
column3: bactéries et autres  agents pathogènes dans le but de provoquer une maladie ou le décès d’êtres humains
column4: d’animaux ou de  cultures.    Depuis les lettres contaminées au bacille du charbon de 2001
column5: le Département de la Santé publique de  Chicago (Chicago Department of Public Health) travaille en collaboration étroite avec les agences  locales
column6: nationales et fédérales pour surveiller et se préparer à un incident potentiel de bioterreur
column7: afin de  protéger la santé et la vie des habitants.    Cliquez ici pour plus d’informations sur les agents spécifiques du bioterrorisme.       Pandémie de grippe    L’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) estime que chaque année
column8: la grippe touche entre 3 et 5  millions de personnes à travers le monde.  Ici aux États-Unis
column9: les Centres de contrôle et de prévention  des maladies (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column10: CDC) estiment que la grippe cause chaque  année plus de 49 000 décès.  Les CDC décrit la pandémie de grippe comme « une épidémie mondiale  d’un nouveau virus A de la grippe... capable d’infecter facilement la population et de se transmettre d’une  personne à une autre de manière efficace et durable. »      Que pouvez-vous faire pour vous protéger
column11: vous et votre famille ?  • Pratiquez l’étiquette de la toux et de l’éternuement  • Lavez-vous régulièrement les mains  • Dans la mesure du possible
column12: restez chez vous si vous êtes malade  • Faites-vous vacciner !    Cliquez ici pour plus d’informations et consultez le site de CDC.                 www.cityofchicago.org/health

column2: 2016    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1601082    Dear Neighbor
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about  an upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.      By mid-May
column6: Department of Water Management crews will begin the work to install 3
column7: 919 feet of  new 12-inch water main in W. Armitage Avenue
column8: from N. Hamlin Avenue to N. Kedzie Avenue. The  old water main dates back to 1890
column9: and needs to be replaced.     If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column10: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.    By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column12: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column13: to the installation of new  pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.    When we are working in the street
column15: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column19: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column20: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column21: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311    26th Ward Office: 773-395-0143    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016   When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column22: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column23: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column24: we may not be able to give you prior warning.    Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column25: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column27: including  any lead to maintain water quality.      Sediment
column29: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.       (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column30: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.             If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column31: or if you would like your water  tested
column32: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.    Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column33: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column34: taking a shower and  doing laundry.      MeterSave  Lastly
column35: if you don’t already have one
column36: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column37: go to  www.metersave.org.    Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.          Sincerely

column1: 25989`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/FIELD-SUPVSR-II-PARKING-ENFORCEMENT_7480.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code:  7480  Operation and Construction Service  River
column2: Harbor and Transportation Group  Parking Attendance Series   Field Supervisor II - Parking Enforcement       CLASS TITLE:      CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under general supervision
column3: the class  functions as a second level supervisor
column4: overseeing parking enforcement  activities in an assigned geographic area; and performs related duties  as required.    ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Monitors field operations to ensure proper staff  coverage and effective enforcement of parking regulations in an  assigned area; meets with supervisory staff to review staffing
column5: work  priorities and status of special assignments; approves work schedules  and makes necessary revisions to ensure efficiency of work operations;  establishes and implements work policies and procedures to ensure  optimum productivity; meets with supervisory staff to communicate  procedural changes and discuss special projects; reviews productivity  reports and evaluates performance of subordinate staff; coordinates  and participates in the training of parking enforcement staff;  responds to atypical or sensitive complaints and inquiries from  aldermanic offices and the general public; works with departmental  managers and other city departments to coordinate parking enforcement  activities; represents the department at community meetings to provide  information on parking enforcement activities and programs; prepares  management reports on work accomplishment.    RELATED DUTIES:  Coordinates special parking enforcement initiatives;  may testify in administrative and court hearings on parking  enforcement operations.     MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience.  Three years of progressively responsible  experience in the enforcement of parking regulations and restrictions
column6: including one year of supervisory experience
column7: or an equivalent  combination of training and experience.  A valid Illinois driver’s  license is required.    Knowledge
column8: Abilities and Skill.  Good knowledge of the city’s parking  ordinances.  Good knowledge of the city’s parking enforcement policies  and practices.  Good knowledge of the city’s geography.  Good  knowledge of supervisory and management theory and practices.             Code:  7480  Operation and Construction Service  River
column9: Harbor and Transportation Group  Parking Attendance Series       CLASS TITLE:      Ability to manage parking enforcement activities in a large geographic  area.  Ability to establish work policies and procedures. Ability to   Field Supervisor II - Parking Enforcement (Cont’d)   coordinate work operations with other city departments.  Ability to  prepare management reports.    Skill in supervising parking enforcement operations.  Good oral and  written communication skills.  Good analytical skills.     Working Conditions.  Inside: General office environment.  Outside:  Occasional exposure to inclement weather and extreme temperatures.    Equipment.  Standard office equipment including personal computers.            NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive   as possible
column10: there may be other duties which are essential  to particular positions within the class.                  March
column11: 2003  City of Chicago  Department of Personnel
